propositions.text: The narrator is writing a ghost story for a collection, intending to show the evolution from first to second draft, but becomes engrossed and finishes it.
The narrator was initially scared while writing the story.
Hotel rooms are inherently frightening places due to past occupants' experiences.
Mike Enslin arrives at the Dolphin Hotel and encounters the manager, Olin.
Mike feels a sense of dread upon seeing Olin, wishing he had brought his lawyer.
He anticipates Olin might create obstacles to prevent him from entering room 1408.
Olin's demeanor suggests he is uncomfortable or troubled.
Olin asks to speak with Mike in his office.
Mike realizes Olin genuinely fears room 1408 and what Mike might experience there.
Mike insists on taking his own luggage, stating he only has clothes and a toothbrush.
Mike jokingly mentions his "lucky Hawaiian shirt" has "ghost repellent."
In Olin's office, the conversation shifts to Mike's books.
Olin offers Mike a cigar, which Mike declines.
Mike explains he quit smoking nine years prior after his brother died of lung cancer.
Mike asks if smoking is permitted in room 1408.
Mike acknowledges Olin's office as Olin's "little world" where he feels in control.
Olin asks if Mike is still determined to stay in room 1408.
Mike expresses his intention to record their conversation.
Olin browses Mike's books, commenting on their titles and the perceived nature of his work.
Olin quotes titles like "Ten Nights of Ten Haunted Houses."
Olin suggests Mike travels for his writing and implies it's tax-deductible.
Mike asserts his right to occupy room 1408 based on New York law, as it is vacant.
Olin expresses his belief that Mike is mistaken about the situation.
Olin's demeanor shifts from seeking help to a more determined stance.
Olin reveals the history of deaths and supernatural occurrences associated with room 1408.
Olin states that room 1408 has a history of deaths, including suicides, overdoses, and accidental deaths.
Five men and one woman jumped from the room's window.
Three women and one man died of overdoses in the room.
One man hanged himself in the closet in 1970.
Randolph Hyde cut his wrists and genitals.
Olin mentions that electronic devices malfunction in room 1408.
Watches may run backward or stop.
Calculators and cell phones are also affected.
Pagers may turn on by themselves even when turned off.
Olin explains that the room has been vacant since 1978, with only monthly cleanings.
The cleaning staff, Veronica and Celeste, had a unique rapport with the room.
Celeste died of a heart condition, possibly exacerbated by the room.
Olin describes an incident where a maid, Romy Van Gelder, temporarily lost her sight after touching the TV.
Olin believes that the room's "poison" affects people differently, with some being more sensitive.
Olin asserts that the room is not haunted by ghosts but by something else, something malevolent.
Olin states that 1408 is on the "13th floor" in spirit, as the numbers add up to thirteen.
Olin mentions that even after simple cleanings, the air inside the room feels stuffy and dusty.
Olin recounts an incident where a maintenance engineer died of a brain hemorrhage the day after inspecting the room.
Mike is determined to enter room 1408, despite Olin's warnings.
Mike questions the validity of Olin's claims, attributing them to superstition or hotel tradition.
Mike believes that the suicides are "cluster effect" material for his book.
Mike notices that Olin becomes more timid and subservient as they approach the elevator.
Mike observes that the elevator skips the 13th floor, going directly from 12 to 14.
Mike asks why Olin doesn't fake a tenant for room 1408 to avoid issues.
Olin explains that he fears accusations of fraud and losing his job if the truth about the room's vacancy is discovered.
Mike feels unsettled by Olin's sincere belief in the room's malevolence.
Mike enters the 14th floor and proceeds towards room 1408.
Mike's legs feel heavy, and he sees Olin's pale, sweating face in the closing elevator doors.
Olin's final plea to Mike is to reconsider entering the room.
Mike's experience in room 1408 is summarized by a recording and his perception of the door.
A ten-minute recording from Mike's mini-recorder is the most interesting artifact from his time in room 1408.
The recording is slightly burned but still audible.
The recorder itself is a sentimental item for Mike, a gift from his ex-wife.
Mike uses the recorder to capture anecdotes from his "field trips."
Before entering room 1408, Mike perceives the door as being crooked.
He interprets this as a directorial technique in horror films.
The crookedness causes a slight feeling of nausea, similar to seasickness.
Upon checking, Mike realizes the door is straight, and he suspects Olin's manipulation.
He then perceives the door as crooked again, this time leaning to the right.
This perception intensifies the nausea, which he compares to being on a stormy ship.
Mike realizes there is a closed-circuit camera in the hallway, suggesting Olin is watching him.
Mike resolves to proceed despite the psychological manipulation.

concepts.name: Ghost Story
concepts.context: The narrator's initial intention for writing the story, the genre of Mike's books, and the subject of the hotel's alleged haunting.

concepts.name: Room 1408
concepts.context: The central setting of the narrative, the subject of Olin's warnings, and the location of Mike's experience.

concepts.name: Olin (Manager)
concepts.context: The hotel manager who tries to dissuade Mike from entering room 1408 and provides much of the historical context.

concepts.name: Mike Enslin
concepts.context: The protagonist, a writer of ghost stories, who insists on staying in room 1408.

concepts.name: Dolphin Hotel
concepts.context: The location of the story and room 1408.

concepts.name: Haunting/Supernatural
concepts.context: The core theme of the story, discussed through Olin's accounts and Mike's skepticism.

concepts.name: Death/Suicide
concepts.context: A significant aspect of room 1408's history, recounted by Olin.

concepts.name: Fear
concepts.context: The emotions experienced by the narrator, Mike, and Olin in relation to the room.

concepts.name: Recording Device
concepts.context: Mike's mini-recorder, used to document conversations and experiences.

concepts.name: Law/Rights
concepts.context: Mike's reliance on legal rights to secure the room and Olin's fear of legal repercussions.

concepts.name: Investigation/Research
concepts.context: Mike's method of writing and Olin's research into the room's history.

concepts.name: Illusion/Perception
concepts.context: Mike's experience with the crooked door and the potential manipulation by Olin.

concepts.name: Skepticism
concepts.context: Mike's initial attitude towards the supernatural elements of room 1408.

concepts.name: Belief
concepts.context: Olin's strong conviction about the room's malevolence, contrasted with Mike's skepticism.

concepts.name: History
concepts.context: The past events and records associated with room 1408.

concepts.name: Sanity/Mental State
concepts.context: The potential psychological impact of room 1408 on its occupants.

concepts.name: Superstition
concepts.context: Mike's initial dismissal of Olin's warnings as mere superstition.

concepts.name: Manipulation
concepts.context: Mike suspects Olin of psychologically manipulating him.

concepts.name: Nausea/Discomfort
concepts.context: Mike's physical reaction to the perceived crookedness of the door.

concepts.name: Writer's Process
concepts.context: Mike's methods of research and writing, including field trips and recording.

hierarchy.structure: The document follows a narrative arc, beginning with the author's framing of the story, introducing the protagonist and antagonist in conflict, detailing the antagonist's warnings and the room's history, and culminating in the protagonist's entry into the room and his subjective experience of its effects.
